definitions.definition: the floor or ground at the bottom of a doorway, considered as the entrance to a building or room

examples.text: She stood hesitating on the threshold.

definitions.definition: the level at which something starts to happen or have an effect

examples.text: He has a low **boredom threshold** *(= he gets bored easily)*.
I have a high **pain threshold** *(= I can suffer a lot of pain before I start to react)*.
My earnings are just above the **tax threshold** *(= more than the amount at which you start paying tax)*.
The number of people with the disease is reaching a critical threshold.
They earn wages below the decency threshold set by the EU.

definitions.definition: the point just before a new situation, period of life, etc. begins

examples.text: She felt as though she was on the threshold of a new life.

wordOrigin: Old English therscold, threscold; related to German dialect Drischaufel; the first element is related to thresh (in a Germanic sense ‘tread’), but the origin of the second element is unknown.
